Problem:
Consider the integral transformation \\(\\mathcal{L}(f)(s) = \\int_0^{\\infty} e^{-st} f(t) dt\\), which defines the Laplace Transform of a time-domain function \\(f(t)\\). We explore how the application of a multiplier function \\(g(t) = e^{at}\\) affects this transformation, where \\(a\\) is a real number.

If we apply the function \\(g(t)\\) to \\(f(t)\\) resulting in the transformed function \\(h(t) = e^{at}f(t)\\), and compute the Laplace Transform, will the resulting transform \\(\\mathcal{L}(h)(s)\\) be equal to the original transform \\(\\mathcal{L}(f)(s)\\) just shifted by \\(-a\\)?
Explanation: The multiplier \\(e^{at}\\) in the time domain corresponds to a shift in the Laplace Transform domain. According to the shifting property of the Laplace Transform, \\(\\mathcal{L}(e^{at} f(t))(s) = \\mathcal{L}(f)(s-a)\\), effectively shifting the transform of \\(f(t)\\) by \\(-a\\).
